content: The Reinsurance International Solvency Standards Evaluation Board Act of 2008 establishes a board to evaluate reinsurance supervisory systems in the US and other jurisdictions to ensure adequate capital and risk management standards. The Board established by the Reinsurance International Solvency Standards Evaluation Board Act of 2008 is a nonprofit corporation with succession until dissolved by Congress. It is not a government agency and its members are not considered federal government employees. The Board is subject to the District of Columbia Nonprofit Corporation Act. The Reinsurance International Solvency Standards Evaluation Board Act of 2008 establishes a Board with seven members appointed by the President based on expertise in reinsurance matters. A majority of members must have reinsurance regulatory expertise from lists submitted by State insurance regulatory authorities. Each member serves a seven-year term. The Reinsurance International Solvency Standards Evaluation Board Act of 2008 establishes a Board with seven members appointed by the President based on expertise in reinsurance matters. Members serve seven-year terms, with initial appointees serving staggered terms ranging from one to six years. The President or designee may prohibit or suspend Board actions deemed significantly contrary to the public interest. The duties of the Board include establishing standards to evaluate reinsurance supervisory systems, conducting evaluations, certifying compliant systems, developing uniform regulation standards, and managing the Board's operations. Additionally, the Board evaluates and certifies reinsurance supervisory systems in accordance with set standards. The Board establishes uniform standards for reinsurance supervisory systems of States and foreign jurisdictions to ensure adequate capital, risk management, and prudential supervision. Procedures are set for entities to request evaluation of these systems' compliance with the standards, with evaluations conducted upon payment of a fee determined by the Board. The Board certifies compliance with reinsurance supervisory system standards, publishes certifications for 12 months, and allows public notice and comment in the process. SEC. 7 states that the domiciliary State of a ceding insurer must treat a reinsurer from another jurisdiction the same as those in good standing in the domiciliary State for reinsurance credit if the jurisdiction is certified and the reinsurer is in good standing. It also preempts any State laws that are inconsistent with this. SEC. 8 aims to facilitate uniform reinsurance standards. SEC. 8 aims to develop proposed uniform standards for reinsurance regulation to improve various aspects, especially where consensus standards or conflicts of law have emerged. The Board will report any proposed standards to appropriate State and Federal entities. The Board, in addition to other powers granted by the Act, has the authority to sue and be sued, conduct operations in any state without regard to state laws, acquire property, and hire employees. The Board has the authority to elect or appoint officers, define their duties, establish personnel policies, allocate fees, enter into agreements, and conduct necessary operations as granted by the Act. The Board establishes rules and bylaws for its operation, delegation of functions, and to carry out the Act. It coordinates with other agencies as needed. The Act defines key terms such as Board, ceding insurer, domiciled, domiciliary state, insurance, and reinsurance. LOAN FOR INITIAL FUNDING." The Secretary of the Treasury will provide a $10,000,000 loan to the Board for operational costs, to be repaid within 5 years with interest. Appropriations are authorized for necessary costs under the Federal Credit Reform Act of 1990. The term is defined in section 502 of the Federal Credit Reform Act of 1990 for the loan under this section.
